comments.author: plenty-sunshine1111
comments.body:
https://preview.redd.it/fq9d4evtgl8e1.jpeg?width=1260&format=pjpg&auto=webp&s=a353d87899f2e1ab199fe80267c915e7320a7d50

If this was to make us Google the menagerie it has worked on me. The animals were cramped and in its long history they were very badly treated but I think from most accounts they weren't living in little cubby holes in a sort of museum space. According to [this](https://historynavigator.org/2018/03/04/the-animals-in-the-tower-a-brief-history-of-the-royal-menagerie/) brief history, conditions were much improved towards the end. I suspect the original picture is simplistic.

comments.author: SherbertResident2222
comments.body:
Yes, can confirm. I went on a school trip there was a child. They had weird rules and limited the colours of clothes that could be worn otherwise the animals would get upset. It was very tidy and clean.

I suspect some of the animals were either brain damaged or injured when captured as they seemed very tame and didn’t look like animals these days.

comments.author: Electrical-Rush-3538
comments.body:
It was known as Londons first Zoo and was there for over 600 years beginning in the 1200's with Leopards , Polar bears and an Elephant.
Housing animals given to Old King's and Queens by other heads of state and explorers.
When it closed many animals were moved to the now London Zoo situated in Londons Regent Park.

comments.author: lightestspiral
comments.body:
Apparently so, yes

>The Tower of London Menagerie did have a somewhat similar appearance to the drawing you described. The menagerie, which operated from the 1200s to 1835, housed a variety of exotic animals, including lions, a polar bear, and an elephant2. The animals were kept in relatively small, confined spaces, often in separate towers or enclosures within the Tower. Visitors could pay to see these animals, and the menagerie was a popular attraction for Londoners and visitors alike.

>The historical records and illustrations suggest that the conditions were quite cramped and not ideal for the animals, but the concept of displaying wild animals in this manner was common at the time

-Copilot

comments.author: peachesnplumsmf
comments.body:
Because God forbid you take 3 seconds to look at one of the many reliable and available sources? The AI bots will make shit up if you ask them for information as they're reading each word as its own thing and putting together a guess based on what's said a lot not what's true.

If you ask an AI for sources formatted academically it'll make them up, it'll confidently give you what looks like a solid reference list but is complete bullshit. AI is a great tool but you cannot use it like this and actually get good results.
